results.title: Perilous, Roadless Jungle Becomes a Path of Desperate Hope
results.abstract: The recent surge at the Mexican border is likely to grow as more migrants, mostly Haitian, risk everything negotiating the notorious Darién Gap on their way to the United States.
results.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Natalie Kitroeff, Sofía Villamil and Federico Rios

results.title: As Bikers Throng the Streets, ‘It’s Like Paris Is in Anarchy’
results.abstract: An ecologically minded experiment to make Paris a cycling capital of Europe has led to a million people now pedaling daily — and to rising tensions with pedestrians.

multimedia.caption: People riding their bikes on the cross of Rue de Rivoli and boulevard Sebastopol — two main bicycles lanes in central Paris during the morning rush hour, in September.

results.title: Duterte Says He Will Retire Rather Than Seek the Vice Presidency
results.abstract: The Philippine president, whose term ends next year, had been expected to seek the No. 2 office, but said he would not do so “in obedience to the will of the people.”

results.title: Battered Towns in England’s North Test Johnson’s Plan to ‘Level Up’
results.abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has made far-reaching promises to spread the good life beyond prosperous southeastern England to neglected parts in the middle and North of the country.

results.title: Romans Choose From a Crowded Field to Run a Chaotic City
results.abstract: Rome has defied efforts to make basic services work, and the incumbent mayor lags in the polls, with no shortage of rivals hoping to take her place.
results.byline: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Emma Bubola

multimedia.caption: Uncollected trash lined the sidewalk in the Portuense district of Rome this past week.

results.title: U.K. Aims to Ease Trucker Shortage With Visas Into 2022
results.abstract: The decision extended an earlier move to offer three-month visas to foreign drivers, and came as the government also called on military drivers to help resolve a fuel distribution crisis.

multimedia.caption: A fuel delivery in Hersham, England, on Thursday. Long lines have persisted at some gas stations, even as the government says distribution is returning to normal.

results.title: Violent Crime Spikes Among Arabs in Israel as Officials Admit Neglect
results.abstract: Killings of Arabs by Arabs have soared in Israel. The prevailing assumption, an official said, was “as long as they are killing each other, that’s their problem.”

results.title: Pakistan in Talks With Taliban Militants, Even as Attacks Ramp Up
results.abstract: Prime Minister Imran Khan said his government was in preliminary negotiations with factions of the Pakistani Taliban, but details remained murky.

results.abstract: This is not the first time the North has launched missiles or otherwise shown off its arsenal while suggesting that it was open to talks.

results.abstract: A Croatian wine, Prosek, seeks an official designation, and Prosecco makers are up in arms. But they also can’t agree on what, exactly, should be called Prosecco.

results.title: Europe’s Social Democrats Show Signs of Life, but France Poses a Roadblock
results.abstract: Center-left parties have won a string of victories, capped by Olaf Scholz’s win in Germany. Yet, France’s struggling Socialists threaten hopes for a broader social democratic revival.

multimedia.caption: The mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party, declaring her candidacy for the French presidency in September. Rather than getting an expected bounce in the polls, her approval ratings have drifted lower, a reflection of the party’s struggles.

results.title: After 100 Years, a Royal Wedding in Russia Evokes Days of the Czars
results.abstract: For the groom, a Romanov and descendant of the imperial throne, and his Italian bride, the wedding represents the pinnacle of their attempts to re-establish a monarchic presence in Russia’s public life.

multimedia.caption: Grand Duke George Mikhailovich Romanov and Victoria Romanovna Bettarini attending their wedding ceremony at the Saint Isaac’s Cathedral in Saint Petersburg, on Friday.

results.title: He Sees Migrants as ‘Modern Slaves,’ and Has Devoted His Life to Helping Them
results.abstract: The Rev. Daniel Alliët, for whom Jesus was a “political revolutionary,” has made it his life’s mission to fight for the rights of undocumented migrants, to the chagrin of some other clergy members.

results.title: In a Surge of Military Flights, China Tests and Warns Taiwan
results.abstract: For two straight days, Beijing sent a record number of planes near the island, Taiwan said, a display of strength that underscored Chinese demands for unification.
results.byline: By Chris Buckley and Amy Qin

multimedia.caption: An undated photo from Taiwan’s defense ministry showing a Chinese H-6 bomber. The ministry said H-6 bombers were among the planes that China flew near the island on Friday.

results.abstract: Shot dead by gunmen, he had compiled a list of those who perished in the hope that the data could be used as evidence in international courts.

results.title: Stanley Tucci’s Passion Was Acting. Now, It’s Food.

results.title: A fire kills seven people in a Romanian hospital’s Covid ward.
results.abstract: The fire was the third in a Romanian hospital in less than a year, underscoring the precarious state of the nation’s health care system.

results.title: In Portugal, There Is Virtually No One Left to Vaccinate
results.abstract: Portugal is among the most highly vaccinated countries in the world. Vice Adm. Henrique Gouveia e Melo, who led the campaign, said there was a key to his success: Keep politics out of it.
results.byline: By Marc Santora and Raphael Minder

results.title: Australia accelerates its plans to allow international travel.
results.abstract: Travel bans will begin to lift in November for citizens and permanent residents, depending on vaccination rates.

results.title: The World Wants Greenland’s Minerals, but Greenlanders Are Wary
results.abstract: The island has rare elements needed for electric cars and wind turbines. But protesters are blocking one project, signaling that mining companies must tread carefully.

results.title: Why Diversity Seems Easier Said Than Done in Politics
results.abstract: Minority members say they need to work twice as hard in a political system with “two sets of rules.”

multimedia.caption: “How parties engage with local communities — it’s one-sided, it’s not participatory,” said Tu Le, a lawyer and the daughter of Vietnamese migrants.

results.title: A Princess Is Set to Be Wed. But It’s No Fairy Tale.
results.abstract: Princess Mako of Japan will forgo the trappings of royal nuptials when she marries her college boyfriend, a commoner, after a long and arduous engagement.

multimedia.caption: Princess Mako of Japan is set to marry her fiancé, a commoner named Kei Komuro, on Oct. 26.
